ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained insight to the discipline of ethnography and the ethics of ethnography. I learned about many large scale disasters that are have occured and continue to occur in the United States today. I also learned that it is challenging to articulate the impact of these disasters while we studied people's attempts to do so.

I learned about current environmental injustices that affect marginalized communities. I learned how to write authentic and correct ethnographies. I learned how to put these texts in conversation with one another to make comments or analyze current structural injustices in which all of us exist within, that can be very hard to pinpoint or define.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
1. Strengths-- continuity of topics across classes, engaging readings, open seminar w/ good collaboration
2. Weaknesses-- books were hard to aquire (library books were limited & reserved books were put in Marx... but perhaps should have been held in Bass for ease)

I found the syllabus texts extremely interesting!! I like how the course provided brief overviews of different environmental injustices. We took deep dives into different topics each week which I appreciated, however it was emotionally draining. I found the discussion posts very engaging too, I really enjoyed the creative responses that each student had the option of completing. It helped me grapple with the emotional taxing. I would have appreciated brief structured lectures during each class, especially because we met only once a week, to give us an overview of definitions, key points and structural inequalities at play in each text. I think the lectures would have provided the class discussions with more structure than just simply discussing. I also thought that submitting drafts of the final essay during reading week was time consuming and stressful. I would have appreciated just submitting one final draft to complete the class during reading week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are looking for an opportunity to think deeply about existential world threatening topic with cool people.

Yes, I enjoyed the readings in this course. I learned so much about current injustices around the world and how to think critically about the enthographers covering their stories. I found the creative weekly discussion posts very helpful and interesting. I learned a lot from my classmates and my professors. The class felt a little long a times though, and I wished we dove deeper into the historical or political informations that led to these injustices.
